subject: Re: [junit] JUnit behaviour
msgSnippet: Seems I failed to make myself clear. Imagine two classes class Super { @Before void beforeSuper() .. ] class Sub extends Super { @Before void beforeSub1() ...
messageBody:
Seems I failed to make myself clear.

Imagine two classes

class Super {
@Before void beforeSuper() ..
]

class Sub extends Super {
@Before void beforeSub1() ...
@Before void beforeSub2() ...
}

My educated guess is that beforeSuper will always be executed first, but
that there is no guarantee whatsoever in which order beforeSub1 and
beforeSub2 will be executed.

Does that make sense?

Cheers, Ilja

Alexandru Popescu â˜€ schrieb:
> On 09 Apr 2007 05:09:30 -0700, Ilja Preuss <it@...> wrote:
>> My first guess without a closer look at the code would be that it's done
>> so that @Before(Class) methods in subclasses are run before those in
>> superclasses.
>>
>> I don't think there is any guarantee on the order of methods inside one
>> class. I could be wrong, though.
>>
>
> If so, then I would say that this is a possible problem. The
> invocation order should follow the one of initialization and TestNG is
> trying to guarantee this rule (where the superclass is firstly
> initialized), otherwise this is quite a limitation (imagine a scenario
> where the parent class initializes some test data, and the child will
> need to customize it - this will never work).
